tossups.question: The narrator of the book in which this character appears ends the novel by pleading “O God - please bring him back! I shall keep asking You.” When this character performs in a production of A Christmas Carol, he sees his own name and date of death on Scrooge’s gravestone. This character removes the claws from a stuffed armadillo to demonstrate his belief that he is God’s instrument. Barb Wiggin gives him an (*) erection while this character is portraying Baby Jesus in a Christmas pageant. This character’s parents believe him to be “like the Christ Child,” because they never had sex before he was born. This character’s dialogue is always written in all capital letters, and he is killed while saving several Vietnamese orphans from a grenade in Phoenix. For 10 points, identify this diminutive title character of a John Irving novel, named “A Prayer For” him.
tossups.answer: Owen Meany [or Owen Meany; or A Prayer for Owen Meany] <Ed. JO>

tossups.question: Members of this family kept political prisoners in cages next to lions and panthers in a private zoo on their grounds. This family’s private army openly looted the capital city after it was largely destroyed by an earthquake; that army, the National Guard, were also filmed executing ABC newsman Bill Stewart. A member of this family was assassinated with a rocket launcher blast to his Mercedes while in exile in Paraguay. The killing of the editor of La Prensa, Pedro (*) Chamorro, sparked an uprising that led a member of this family known as “Tachito” to steal 400 million dollars from the treasury and flee the country. The Contras were led by former henchmen of this family, who were opposed by the Sandinistas. For 10 points, Anastasio Garcia led what family, which ruled Nicaragua from 1936 to 1979?

With Michael Holman, this man cofounded a noise rock band named Gray, referencing a copy of Gray’s Anatomy, which influenced his work. This man first gained broader attention through a Rene Ricard article titled “Radiant Child.” With Al Diaz, this artist developed a pseudonym that included a copyright symbol; upon retiring that alter ego, this man painted the phrase (*) “SAMO© [same-oh] IS DEAD” around New York. Keith Haring used one of this artist’s motifs in a work titled Pile of Crowns for this artist, which commemorated his 1988 death. This artist’s depiction of a skull broke the auction record for an American artwork in 2017, taking the title from this artist’s collaborator Andy Warhol. For 10 points, name this Haitian-American artist, known for his graffiti-like paintings.

In 2014, an Atlantic article criticized a famous book by this thinker by referencing Piketty's research that capitalism has actually accelerated wealth disparities. Similarly to Nietzsche, this thinker wondered if just making money or being elected to office may be a transcendent challenge in some sense. In a recent book, this thinker said a stable state is strong and modern, follows rule of law and is accountable. In his most famous article, this author claims that only a modern type of (*) government could provide what Plato said was necessary for happiness. This thinker of the book The Origins of Political Order walked back from some of his earlier ideas in his book Trust: Social Virtues and Creation of Prosperity. For 10 points, name this political theorist, who posited that liberal democracies and free market capitalism would end humanity’s sociocultural evolution in The End of History and the Last Man.

In some reactions of this type, the reaction can be “frozen” in a transition state due to agostic effects. A rhodium phosphine catalyst undergoes dissociative substitution to form an alkyl complex, which then undergoes this type of reaction in hydroformylation. Since reactions of this type generate a vacant coordination center, a trapping ligand is often used to prevent the reverse of this type of reaction from occurring. Carbon monoxide uses this mechanism to react with (*) metal-alkyl bonds. The opposite of this type of reaction can be used to convert aldehydes to alkanes, and is known as beta-hydride elimination. This type of reaction often proceeds via a “migratory” mechanism. For 10 points, name this type of reaction in transition metal chemistry, in which a ligand places itself inside a bond.
tossups.answer: Migratory insertion [prompt on migrations with “as part of what reaction?”]

tossups.question: The “King” of this substance, William Crawshay, built a faux-medieval castle overlooking the grounds where his workers produced it at Merthyr Tydfil. This substance was used to build a Methodist chapel, a personal coffin. The first bridge of its type was built by a man nicknamed for being “mad” for this substance, John Wilkinson. Four generations of Quakers named Abraham Darby made innovations in the production of this substance. Glass and this material were used for (*) Joseph Paxton’s Crystal Palace at the Great Exhibition. England’s Industrial Revolution was partly enabled by the use of puddling and coke-fired blast furnaces in the production of this material. For 10 points, what metal’s “pig” form is used to create steel in the Bessemer Process?
tossups.answer: Iron [or cast iron; or wrought iron; or pig iron; do not accept or prompt on “steel”] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: This character claims to have driven a man into “a living humor of madness” by washing his liver “as clean as a sound sheep’s heart.” When asked “But is this all for your father?,” this character responds “No, some of it is for my child’s father.” A poem about this character states that “wintered garments must be lined” and “they that reap must sheaf and bind;” that poem is described as a “bad fruit.” This character jilts (*) Phoebe at the altar, causing her to exclaim “If sight and shape be true / Why then, my love adieu.” The actor playing this character tells the audience “If I were a woman, I would kiss as many of you as had beards that pleased me.” This character orders her love interest to woo her while she is disguised as the boy Ganymede, which occurs after she follows Orlando to the Forest of Arden. For 10 points, name the female lead of As You Like It.
tossups.answer: Rosalind [prompt on Ganymede before it is read] <DS>

tossups.question: The modelling language AMPL is used to formulate problems of this type. Line-search and trust-region are two types of SQP methods for this task. For this task to have a solution, the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions must be satisfied. The Frank-Wolfe algorithm for this task is also known as the conditional gradient method. A probabilistic algorithm for this task slowly reduces a “temperature” variable to change the transition probabilities; that physically inspired algorithm is called (*) simulated annealing. Interior point methods like Karmarkar’s algorithm, or other methods like the simplex algorithm, can be used to solve linear problems of this type. For 10 points, name this task that finds the maximum or minimum value of a function, given some constraints.

One music video recorded by an artist singing in this language contains poorly green screened shots of him dancing in locales such as Antarctica and Easter Island. It’s not French, but one artist who records in this language duetted with Ziggy Marley on his song “Madanite.” The rapper El General and the singer of “We Will Stay Here” are prominent protest musicians in this language. This language is used by a trio of sisters, whose most famous song is an adaptation of a folk song, whose title translates as “love of my heart.” That trio is (*) A-WA. Cheb Mami sings in the rai genre in this language, and a concert by one singer in this language, Umm Kholtoum, caused Muammar Qaddafi to postpone a military coup. For 10 points, name this language spoken in countries such as Algeria and Syria.
tossups.answer: Arabic [or Levantine Arabic; or Mashriqi; or Shaami; or Yemeni; or Egyptian Arabic; or Maghribi Arabic] <JM>

tossups.question: An autobiography from this country describes how, as a child, the author tried to chop off his own head with a cleaver after failing a recitation at his school for the blind. A novel from this country is dictated by a woman scheduled to be executed that evening for stabbing a man to death; that novel about a prostitute is Woman at Point Zero. In a novel from this country, a criminal attempts to shoot his associates Ilish and Rauf but kills the wrong person both times. In that novel, (*) Said Marwan perceives the authorities as dogs chasing him. In a novel from this country home to Nawal el-Saadawi, Yasin debauches himself while his brother Fahmy demonstrates against this country’s British colonizers. That novel about the al-Jawad family is the first in a trilogy named for this country’s capital. For 10 points, name this home country of Taha Hussein and Naguib Mahfouz.

An obscure metaphor about the anointing of full jars of oil appears in a gospel named for this concept, one of the works of the Valentinian Gnostics found at Nag Hammadi. The armor of God described by Paul in Ephesians includes the breastplate of righteousness and a belt of this concept. During his trial, Jesus’s claim that “Everyone who belongs to [this concept] listens to My voice” prompts Pontius Pilate to retort (*) “What is [this concept]?” At the Last Supper, Jesus tells Thomas that “I am the way and the [this concept] and the life.” Pius IX decreed that doctrines could not fail to have this property if they were delivered ex cathedra. For 10 points, everything in the Bible has what property, according to the doctrine of biblical infallibility?

One writer used this language to create a 500 word palindrome which begins “Trace this uneven palindrome.” A novel translated from this language includes Milton’s sonnet “On His Glaucoma,” and the “Living or not living” soliloquy. A work exploring this language repeatedly tells the story of a character who gets told to add a button to his overcoat. An author who used rearrangeable text to write A Hundred Thousand Billion Poems in this language wrote Exercises in Style and founded a literary group whose name is an (*) abbreviation of “workshop of potential literature” in this language. A novel translated by Gilbert Adair follows a group of characters who investigate the disappearance of the letter e from this language, titled A Void. For 10 points, name this language used by Oulipo members Georges Perec, Raymond Queneau, and Jacques Roubaud.

After Henry Frank accused this politician of anti-semitism, he challenged Frank to debate the issues of the campaign “entirely in the Yiddish language.” His sister, Gemma, was held in the Ravensbruck concentration camp as a political prisoner. This man appointed Thomas E. Dewey as a prosecutor to help “drive the bums out of town.” With the help of Robert Moses and Herbert Lehman, he upgraded the infrastructure of the (*) city he led. This politician destroyed Frank Costello’s slot machines with a sledgehammer, and he co-authored a labor bill forbidding employers from forcing employees to sign “yellow-dog” contracts with George Norris. For 10 points, name this Italian-American Mayor of New York City who was called “the Little Flower,” and has an airport named after him.
tossups.answer: Fiorello LaGuardia [or Fiorello Henry LaGuardia; or Fiorello Enrico LaGuardia] <Ed. JO & JM>

tossups.question: Chaudhrey’s disease is associated with the presence of multiple small instances of this organ. Ivemark syndrome results in the development of an incorrect number of this organ. Basophilic nuclear remnants known as Howell-Jolly bodies are a sign of of decreased function of this organ. This organ produces most of the body’s supply of immunoglobulin M. Sections of this organ are separated by the (*) marginal zone. Nixon’s sign and Castell’s sign are used to diagnose enlargements of this organ. Macrophages and monocytes are stored in this organ’s cords of Billroth. This organ breaks down hemoglobin into its constituent amino acids and bilirubin. For 10 points, name this organ of the lymphatic system that filters red blood cells.

In this opera, an important plot point occurs when a character sings the held notes A, G, down to C, and is followed by a rapid section in C-minor, where the chorus scolds that character in a repeated long-short-short pattern. An aria in this opera begins with the notes C, D-flat, F, followed by a descent to a trill on G. That aria follows one in which the character ponders if a particular suitor was “the one.” A melody from this opera begins with a (*) jump from a short F up to a long D, followed by two more short F, D, D jumps. In this opera, Giorgio tells the title character to break up with his son. Near the end of Act I, when Baron Douphol refuses to give a toast, another character in this opera sings the aria “Libiamo ne’lieti calici,” a drinking song. For 10 points, name this opera by Giuseppe Verdi about the love between Alfredo and the title Fallen Woman, Violetta.
tossups.answer: La Traviata [or The Fallen Woman before it is mentioned] <Ed. JS>

tossups.question: One theory holds that these people’s largest subgroup were named for the French city of Rodez, and Duke Henry the Obotrite was nicknamed the “King” of these people. Two groups of these people had adjacent “white” homelands, and one branch of these people were named for their location “by the Elbe.” These people’s first kingdom was established by a Frankish merchant named (*) Samo. They’re not Vikings, but another branch of these people were described by Ibn Fadlan. These people’s lands were taken during the Ostsiedlung, and they established the Great Moravian Empire. Dynasties of these people included the Premyslids. For 10 points, name these people, branches of whom include the Serbs, Czechs, and Russians.
tossups.answer: Slavs [or Czechs; or Bohemians; or Russians; or Polabians; or Serbs; or Croats; do NOT accept any of the ethnic groups mentioned in the last line after question ends] <JM>

tossups.question: A deity from this myth system served the sun and moon gods and ruled over an object this culture considered to be a two-headed serpent with its heads buried. Some young women in this culture known as Virgins of the Sun tended to the sun god’s sacred fire and were also sexual partners of the king. The creator god of this culture’s mythology created the sun, stars, and mankind by blowing into (*) stones after coming from a lake. Much of what is known about this culture’s myth system come from a Royal Commentary of [these people], which describes several leaders known as Apus or Sapas. The chief god worshipped by these people was portrayed on a gold disk with rays and flames, and his sister was named Mama-Kilya. For 10 points, identify these worshippers of Viracocha and Inti, who lived in cities like Machu Picchu.

In the third chapter of a book that primarily advocates this position, an argument based on genetic kinship and conspicuous generosity is used to show that this position is compatible with altruism. The “Ultimate Boeing 747 gambit” is often used to justify this belief, which is represented by the good-natured character of Wolmar in Rousseau’s novel La nouvelle Heloïse. This belief was advocated by the (*) Baron d’Holbach. In “A Letter Concerning Toleration,” Locke argued that “Promises, covenants, and oaths … can have no hold upon” people with this belief. Five arguments against this belief were espoused by Aquinas in Summa Theologica. For 10 points, identify this belief in the nonexistence of a deity.
tossups.answer: Atheism [or secularism; or any answer indicating not believing in Gods; do NOT accept “God is dead;” prompt on agnosticism] <Ed. HB>

tossups.question: A typical single-pole filter shows roll-off of 20 decibels for each increase of frequency by this factor. This is twice the number of dimensions in Kaluza-Klein theory. Since it is the product of the group of space-time translations and the Lorentz group, the Poincaré group has this many generators. After symmetry, this is the number of (*) Einstein field equations, though the Bianchi identities reduce them to six. This is one fewer than the number of dimensions in M-theory, and equal to the number of dimensions in superstring theory. An increase in intensity of one bel represents an increase by a factor of this number, and this is the base of the “common” logarithm. For this number of points, name this number.

(TB). This artist’s painting Cora Kneeling at the Feet of Tamenund depicts a scene from The Last of the Mohicans. One of this man’s paintings was rejected by a man with its title profession, Ithiel Town. That painting by this artist depicts a man laying on a pillar in front of a pyramid and an enormous Greek (*) temple. In another of this man’s works, boats sail in a massive earthen cup. This artist of The Architect’s Dream and The Titan’s Goblet depicted a mossy pillar in the left of one piece, part of a series depicting the rise and fall of an imaginary city. Another painting by this artist shows a gnarled, leaning tree in the foreground as the Connecticut River flows in the distance. For 10 points, name this painter of The Course of Empire series and The Oxbow.

bonuses.leadin: Name the following American geographical features named for early navigators. For 10 points each:
parts: This river, which flows through the cities of Albany and New York, is named for a Dutch explorer sailing under the English flag.
This Greek explorer, who sailed for Spain, names both a strait in Washington state and a tectonic plate that adjoins it.
This Alaskan island chain is named for a Russian navigator. Along with the Near and Rat Islands, it is one of the sub-chains of the Aleutians.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about the first poet known by name, Enheduanna.
answers: Inanna [do NOT accept “Nanna,” who she also served, but who is male]
Sargon the Great [or Sargon of Akkad] <DS>
parts: Her most famous work is an “Exaltation to” this love goddess, which begins by describing her as “Lady of all the divine powers” and “righteous woman clothed in radiance.” Enheduanna was high priestess of this goddess in Ur.

Enheduanna wrote in this language, whose primary dialect was called emegir. Some texts in this language use a variant called emesal in the speech of female deities, but interestingly not those of Enheduanna.
Enheduanna’s writings also provided political support for this man, who was her father. This man united various Sumerian city states into the first Akkadian empire.

bonuses.leadin: A short-lived league formed to oppose these people allegedly rescued the countess of Holland from one of them, who was holding her in Reitberg Castle. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this term, which refers to Medieval German noblemen who extorted tolls from merchants traveling on the Rhine.

The number of robber barons and tolling stations exploded during the Interregnum, during which no one held this title. Prior to the Interregnum, this title was held by Hohenstaufens, such as Frederick Barbarossa.

The Interregnum was ended by the election of the first Habsburg emperor, a man of this name who destroyed many robber castles. The second emperor of this name patronized astronomers such as Kepler and Mannerist artists such as Arcimboldo.

bonuses.leadin: This man’s dialogue with Catholic writer Thomas Merton was published as the essay “Wisdom in Emptiness.” For 10 points each:
answers: D. T. Suzuki [or Suzuki Daisetsu Teitaro]
parts: Name this writer, who compared the thought of Meister Eckhart to concepts such as satori and sunyata in his introductions to an Asian religious school.
Suzuki is best-known for spreading this school of Buddhism to the West. This school emphasizes meditation, sometimes through contemplation of paradoxical sayings called koans.

In Japan, Suzuki popularized the theology of this man, whom he dubbed the “Buddha of the North.” Thousands of 19th-century Americans, including Johnny Appleseed, joined the New Church based on the teachings of this Swedish mystic theologian.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points, answer the following about a philosopher who wouldn’t hesitate to potentially push you down the stairs: Arthur Schopenhauer.
answers: The World as Will and Representation [or Die Welt als Wille und Vorstellung]
parts: Schopenhauer’s doctoral thesis was “On the Fourfold Root of” this concept. This concept, which generally states that all actions must have a cause, was formulated along with the principle of contradiction in the Monadology.

This book, Schopenhauer’s magnum opus, includes a refutation of Kant’s idea that sensation is caused by an outside, unknowable object and instead says that only the human body has both of the title concepts.

This other German pessimistic philosopher said that life is absolutely worthless and was inspired by Kant and Schopenhauer to write his Philosophy of Redemption. Nietzsche criticized this writer, along with von Hartmann and Bahnsen, for not being good pessimists like Schopenhauer in The Gay Science.

bonuses.leadin: This peasant led an uprising centered in Tarnovo that expelled both the Mongols and the ineffectual Tsar Konstantin from his country. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this monarch, a former swineherd who was nicknamed “The Cabbage,” for reasons unknown.

Ivaylo’s reign marked an interregnum in the Asen Dynasty’s rule of this empire. Its forces were defeated at the Battle of the Gates of Trajan by a Byzantine emperor who blinded thousands of its soldiers.
Ivaylo expelled the forces of this Mongol successor state that also controlled most of Southern Russia and was named for the distinct color of its tents.

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, Hodge Backmaker travels from the backwater New York City to an academic co-op called Haggershaven. For 10 points each:
answers: a time machine [or The Time Machine]
Confederate victory in the US Civil War [or any clear equivalent] <Ed. HB & DS>
parts: Identify this 1953 novel by Ward Moore, a work of alternate history depicting a world in which the combustion engine was never invented and Thomas Dewey was elected president.
In Bring the Jubilee, Hodge uses one of these devices designed by Barbara Haggerwells. The Morlocks and Eloi meet the protagonist of an H. G. Wells novel titled for one of these devices.

In his best-known novel, The Guns of the South, noted alternate history writer Harry Turtledove wrote about a South African group who use time travel to achieve this result. Hodge Backmaker accidentally reverses this result in Bring the Jubilee, giving us our present timeline.

bonuses.leadin: This condition may progress to Barrett’s esophagus and different esophageal cancers as stomach content moves back up into the esophagus. For 10 points each:
answers: gastroesophageal reflux disease [or GERD; or acid reflux; prompt on heartburn]
H2 inhibitors [or H2 antagonists; or H2 blockers; or H2RA] <Ed. JS>
parts: Name this condition, which may be caused by a hiatal hernia. In this condition, the lower esophageal sphincter fails.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease is often treated with this class of medications. This class of medication works by preventing the release of a certain ion into the gastric lumen by parietal cells, thus decreasing the amount of acid in the stomach.

Proton-pump inhibitor took over the treatment of excess stomach acid from this class of drugs, examples of which are cimetidine and betazole. These drugs inhibit a certain receptor that binds a messenger released from enterochromaffin like-cells.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about mixed languages. For 10 points each:
answers: Nicaraguan Sign Language [or Idioma de Señas de Nicaragua; do NOT accept or prompt on “Lenguaje de Señas de Nicaragua”] <Ed. JM>
parts: These simplified mixed languages often result from trade or other contact between two groups without a language in common. They are contrasted with creoles, which result when these languages acquire fixed grammatical structure and native speakers.
Orphans in this modern-day country created a German-based creole called Unserdeutsch. This island country is known for having over 800 distinct languages, making creoles rather necessary to get by.

Advocates of universal grammar often point to this language as an example of a spontaneously generated creole. This language is best understood as a mixture of hundreds of different “home-sign” systems, combined when its users attended a boarding school together.

bonuses.leadin: This model improved on an earlier model of Einstein’s by removing the assumption of complete independence between the oscillators. For 10 points each:
answers: ideal gas law constant [or universal gas constant]
parts: Name this model of a solid, which predicts a temperature cubed dependence of heat capacity at low temperature.

The Debye model recovers the Dulong-Petit law at high temperatures, which predicts that the heat capacity is three times this number, which is the constant of proportionality between P V and n T in a similarly named law.
This parameter describes variations in the heat capacity with temperature not captured by the Debye model, due to thermal expansion.

bonuses.leadin: Social Gospel clergyman Josiah Strong reissued his racist book Our Country in response to this document. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this document, the first to be compiled with the tabulating machine invented by Herman Hollerith. Part of this document includes a famous passage stating that “There can hardly be said to be a frontier line.”
This congressman used the data of the 1890 census to set the quotas for new immigrants in the Immigrant Act of 1924, which he co-sponsored and names with Senator David Reed.

Under George Horace Lorimer, this magazine popularized the idea of immigration quotas based on the 1890 census. This once-weekly magazine printed the Four Freedoms paintings of its frequent cover artist, Norman Rockwell.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about European empires trying to connect their colonies in Africa. For 10 points each:
parts: This crisis erupted when France attempted to dispatch an army to defeat an uprising in its namesake Sudanese city, before being forced to back down and abandon their dreams of transcontinental empire by the British.
This object established Portuguese claims to a transcontinental empire. It was named for the color used to fill in territories between Angola and Mozambique.

Following the acquisition of German Tanganyika, the British were in a position to build Cecil Rhodes’ dreamed-of transcontinental railroad between these two cities, now the capitals of former British colonies at the Northern and Southern ends of the continent.

bonuses.leadin: At the end of this scene, the protagonist looks towards the “humming hive” of a darkening city, and declares “Henceforth there is war between us.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this scene that ends an 1835 novel, during which empty carriages bearing the coat of arms of the Comte de Restaud and the Baron de Nucingen follow a procession.

Like his character Père Goriot, this author was given a shabby funeral at the Pere Lachaise. Some people believe that this author of the Human Comedy series died from caffeine poisoning, as he was known to drink as many as fifty cups per day.
The angelic Père Goriot is often contrasted with Felix, a miserly, tyrannical father in this other Balzac novel. The title character of this novel is a girl who falls in love with her cousin Charles.

bonuses.leadin: Name the following countries that are the number one exporters of bauxite on their continents. All other countries have inferior bauxite. For 10 points each,
parts: This country, whose impoverished Blue Mountains region contains most of its bauxite mines, exports the most bauxite of any country in the Americas.
This West African nation, the first in its region to declare independence from France, developed its bauxite industry with Czechoslovak and Soviet assistance under its first leader, Sekou Toure.
This country exports a lot of bauxite, along with a lot of other minerals. Its town of Coober Pedy is the world’s largest opal mine, and its cities of Kalgoorlie and Adelaide are also mining centers.

bonuses.leadin: This non-Jesus figure appears at the left of one painting retrieving a coin from a fish’s mouth, and on the right of that painting delivering the coin to a taxman. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this figure, whose life is celebrated in paintings from the Brancacci chapel, including The Tribute Money. Clothed in orange and blue, he also appears “enthroned,” baptizing neophytes, and reprimanding Ananias to death.

Felice Brancacci commissioned this artist to decorate the Brancacci chapel in honour of his uncle Pietro. Many of those decorations were finished by Filippino Lippi following this man’s untimely death at 26.
Masaccio also created a painting for the Brancacci chapel in which Saint Peter heals the sick in this way, without looking directly at them.

bonuses.leadin: A mixture known as white liquor in this process consists of water, lye, and sodium sulfide, among other fun chemicals. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process, which breaks down lignin and hemicellulose to produce pulp.
The Kraft process is a key component of the production of this commodity, which might be lined or bond quality. It only takes one sheet to make a difference.
Paper which is acid-free does not contain this compound, formerly commonly used to help size the paper. This compound is also commonly found in styptic pencils to stem bleeding.

bonuses.leadin: In one poem, the narrator describes following the “hob-nailed wake” of this figure in his youth, but concludes that “today / it is [this figure] who keeps stumbling / behind me, and will not go away.” For 10 points each:
answers: Seamus Heaney’s father [or alternate titles for father, such as dad; prompt on the narrator’s father]
parts: Name this figure. Another poem addressed to this figure describes him haggling at a cattle market, and states that “Your stick was parked behind the door and stands there still.”

Possibly the best known poem about Heaney’s dad is this one, in which the author imagines a “rasping sound” outside his window from “twenty years away” and states “By God, the old man could handle a spade.”
“Follower,” “Ancestral Photograph” and “Digging” were all published in this 1966 Heaney collection, his first to be published.

bonuses.leadin: This composer’s keyboard sonata sets include ones titled “Prussian” and “Wurttemberg,” and he wrote the influential treatise Essay on the True Art of Playing Keyboard Instruments. For 10 points each:
answers: Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach [prompt on Bach; do NOT accept “J.S. Bach”}
Frederick the Great [prompt on Frederick; or Frederick II]
parts: Name this composer who, along with his younger siblings and half-siblings, contributed to a “Notebook” of different pieces that their father gave to his second wife.
For much of his prime, C. P. E. Bach was under the employment of this ruler, who was the dedicatee of J. S. Bach’s The Musical Offering. This Hohenzollern was taught flute by Johann Quantz.

C. P. E. Bach pioneered this style of musical composition, popular in the court music of Frederick the Great, that used dissonant melodic leaps, sudden changes of dynamics, and appoggiaturas that represented sighs.

bonuses.leadin: After falling into obscurity, this short story was re-popularized by the Feminist Press in the 1970s. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Charlotte Perkins Gilman short story, in which the narrator goes insane after she is imprisoned in a colorful room as part of a “rest cure.”

Elaine Hedges’ afterword to “The Yellow Wallpaper” analyzes this unnamed figure, who the story’s narrator sees creeping behind the bars in the wall’s pattern. Sherlock Holmes refers to Irene Adler with this epithet.
Gilman’s best-known novel is this utopian story about a society inhabited entirely by women, where children are born parthenogenetically to eugenically-selected mothers.

bonuses.leadin: This device maintains a constant volume in order to maintain a consistent heat capacity. For 10 points each:
answers: bomb calorimeter [prompt on a partial answer]
parts: Name this dangerous sounding device, used to measure the heat of combustion.
This type of calorimetry measures the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a sample and a reference in lock-step. It is similar to, but distinct from, DTA.

A third type of calorimetry is this technique, used to determine the properties of interactions in solutions. The change in the temperature of a buffer solution is measured after injection of the compounds of interest and compared to a reference buffer.
